chapter.title: Getting started
chapter.para: This chapter will help you to understand the basics of the D2S application framework and how to work with it.

section.title: The human resources (HR) sample application
section.para: The human resources application is a simple yet comprehensive business application targeted at managing a company organization and the employees who work in it. It will demonstrate how D2S can handle a domain model with its relationships and its constraints, present it to the end-user for manipulation through various built-in views and actions, handle security through profile management, distribute the frontend across the network, ...

section.title: The domain model
section.para: To quickly introduce the HR domain model, let's dive into the following UML class diagrams. As a general rule to make the diagrams more readable attributes must in fact be considered as getter / setter pairs.
The commons class diagram describes commonly used interfaces and classes.
A few hints :

listitem.para: The traceable interface is implemented by entities for which we need to record when it was saved for the first time and when it was last updated. Of course, these tracing elements must be made read-only to the end-user since they are automatically managed by the application.
The nameable is implemented by entities having a name. A name has a max length of 64 characters and is mandatory.

The contact information component is used by entities that have contact details (address, phone, email, ...). A contact information points to one and only one city. A city is nameable and has a zip code of maximum length 10 characters.
An event is a piece of text which is traceable

section.para: The employees class diagram describes what an employee is.
A few hints :

listitem.para: An employee is nameable and traceable. An employee has :
a first name (his last name is inherited by the nameable interface)
a social security number which is composed by exactly 10 digits
a gender (male or female)
a birth date
a hire date in the company
a contact information
An employee must provide a method to compute his age based on his birth date.
An employee has an ordered list of events.

section.para: The organization class diagram describes how the company is structured in departments and teams.
A few hints :

listitem.para: A company is structured in organizational units. An organizational unit may be a department or a team. An organizational unit has an identifier (ouId) which is formed by a 2 letter code followed by a dash followed by a 3 digit number (IS-001 for instance). Each organizational unit has a manager who is an employee of the company it belongs to. An employee can at most manage one organizational unit. An organizational unit is nameable, traceable and has contact information as well as a company has.
The company may have one or more departments and a department belongs to one and only one company.
A department may have one or more teams and a team belongs to one and only one department. Each team is composed by one or more employees.
An employee belongs to one and only one company. An employee may belong to zero or more teams.

section.title: The application modules
section.para: The HR application is divided in 3 modules.

section.title: The organization management module
section.para: This module manages a company structure in terms of organizational units. The end-user may create/delete/update a company, create/delete/update its organizational units and structure them in the organization. The end-user may compose the employee teams, assign an organisational unit manager but won't be able to create/update/delete an employee. The organization must be displayed in a hierarchical (tree) view.

section.title: The employees management module
section.para: This module manages a company staff. The end-user can retrieve the company employees and create/update/delete an employee. The end-user will be able to create/update/delete events for an employee and may re-order them in an unspecified manner as needed.

section.title: The master data management module
section.para: This module manages the application master data. As of now, the master data are only made of the cities available to compose the addresses.

section.title: The profiles
section.para: The HR application offers 3 profiles.

section.title: The organization manager profile
section.para: A logged-in user having the organization manager profile will be granted access to the organization management module as well as the master data management module but he won't be able to create a new company.

section.title: The staff manager profile
section.para: A logged-in user having the staff manager profile will be granted access to the employee management module as well as the master data management module but he won't be able to re-order the events assigned to an employee.

section.title: The administrator profile
section.para: The administrator profile has no restriction in the application.

section.title: Layering the application
section.para: Now that we have collected the detailed specifications, it's time to feed the framework with them. As we saw before, most of the job will consist of describing the different layers in a structured way. But before going further, let's define the best practices regarding the logical layering of a typical D2S application (although these practices may generally apply to any well designed application). We will define 3 logical layers from the bottom to the top :

listitem.para: The domain model
The backend
The frontend

section.para: This organisation will help to prevent cyclic dependencies between layers since each layer will be allowed to use lower ones but not higher ones (e.g. : the backend may use the domain model but not the frontend).

Of course, this is a minimal logical layering. Each of this layer may be further divided in subparts depending on the software complexity. For instance the domain model might be divided in master and movement data and the backend and frontend may be divided in modules. It's entirely up to the application designer to tailor these rules. But it surely is the first design activity.
The general architecture diagram introduces this layering strategy.
Let's define now what precisely go in these layers.

section.title: The domain model
section.para: The domain model includes :

listitem.para: The entities. An entity will be described by :
properties along with their constraints and their interceptors
behaviour (business methods, life-cycle interceptors)
integrity enforcements
default presentation elements (name, icon, rendered properties, ordering properties)
relationships to other entities (cardinality, reversibility)
The components. A component has all the characteristics of an entity except that it is not autonomous since It is designed as a structure to be inlined in an entity (e.g. : an address structure).
Other structural elements like common business interfaces.

section.para: We will see later that there virtually any domain model can be extensively described using D2S. This includes for instance polymorphic entities or associations, multiple inheritance, and so on.

section.title: The backend
section.para: The backend includes all the application parts that do not depend on the client :

listitem.para: The actions server parts (which interact with the domain model for instance)
The application modules along with their hierarchies of sub-modules. A module is a top application entry point which is directly accessible by the end user.

The application sub-modules. They form a hierarchy since sub-modules may contain other sub-modules. Each sub-module is an independent application part targeted at accessing the backend data (domain model manipulation, reporting, ...).
The backend controller which holds the user backend application state and its configuration (application modules registration)

section.title: The frontend
section.para: The frontend includes all the application parts that interact directly with the end-user :

listitem.para: The views
The action client parts (which handle user interaction and trigger action server parts)
The client application module parts
The frontend controller which holds the user frontend application state and its configuration (client application modules registration)

section.title: Describing the domain model
section.para: In this chapter, you will learn how to feed the D2S framework with the hr sample domain model description.

section.title: Using the Spring dependency injection container
section.para: Let's go back to the HR sample application. As for every layer introduced above, describing the domain model will consist in assembling D2S description java beans using the Spring framework Dependency Injection Container. To achieve this, you will have to write an XML file that conforms to the spring beans schema. Of course, you can use any text editor but we will encourage you to use at least a schema-aware XML editor like jEdit or even better, use Eclipse and Spring IDE. The latest will offer a lot of productivity enhancement with code completion for the XML elements and attributes as well as for the description bean class names and properties of D2S.
The various description java beans that are provided by D2S are detailed in the next chapter.

We will use the root package com.d2s.framework.hrsample for our application. The domain model description will logically go to the com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model package. In this package, we will create a hrsample-model.xml file as described below :

section.title: Interfaces
section.para: As a starting point, we will describe the commons model part.
The Nameable interface may be described as follow :
section.programlisting: <bean id="Nameable" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicInterfaceDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Nameable" /> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="name" /> <property name="maxLength" value="64" /> <property name="mandatory" value="true" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>

callout.para: This is a standard spring bean definition. We are creating a descriptor bean.
The identifier of this descriptor bean instance for later reference.
Since we are describing a generic interface (which may or may not turn to be an entity) we will use a BasicInterfaceDescriptor as opposed to a BasicEntityDescriptor or BasicComponentDescriptor.
The (fully-qualified) name of this interface.
The property descriptors of this interface descriptor.
The string property descriptor to hold the name property description.
The name of the name property which is "name".
The maximum length of the name property which is 64 characters.
The fact that the name property is mandatory on a Nameable.

section.para: As you can see above, we create an interface descriptor (com.d2s.framework.sample.backend.domain.Nameable) with one property (name) along with its constraints (maxLength and mandatory). This is a fairly simple interface since it has no intrinsic behaviour nor relationships with other components.
So now, lets describe the Traceable interface as follow :
section.programlisting: <bean id="Traceable" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicInterfaceDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Traceable" /> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicDatePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="createTimestamp" /> <property name="type" ref="DATE_TIME" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicDatePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="lastUpdateTimestamp" /> <property name="type" ref="DATE_TIME" /> </bean> </list> </property> <property name="unclonedProperties"> <list> <value>createTimestamp</value> <value>lastUpdateTimestamp</value> </list> </property> </bean>

callout.para: The date property descriptor to hold the createTimestamp property. Same applies for the lastUpdateTimestamp property.
We want to preserve date and time information in this property as opposed to only date information.
Whenever a Traceable component is duplicated, we want exclude the tracing values from the cloning process.

section.para: The Traceable interface description is slightly more complicated than the Nameable interface since not all properties are eligible to cloning (unclonedProperties).

section.title: Generating the code
section.para: It is time now to get our interfaces generated before going further. Let's use the D2S generation tool to make it happen. D2S provides a freemarker template to generate the components that may be easily triggered using a simple ant task. Since this generator explores the spring beans definitions, we first need to declare our hrsample-model.xml as being part of our application. To achieve that, let's create a configuration file named beanRefFactory.xml in the root source folder (without any package) as follow :

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.0.xsd" default-lazy-init="true">
<bean id="hrsample-model-context" class="org.springframework.context.support.ClassPathXmlApplicationContext" lazy-init="true"> <constructor-arg> <list> <value>com/d2s/framework/application/commons.xml</value> <value>com/d2s/framework/tools/entitygenerator/mock.xml</value> <value>com/d2s/framework/hrsample/model/hrsample-model.xml</value> </list> </constructor-arg> </bean> </beans>
The commons bean definitions of the D2S framework.
A configuration file to mock undefined (for the moment) bean references; this file is only used for the component generation phase.
Our application model description file.
This configuration file assembles the necessary spring configuration files for the generator to operate. So we are ready to operate the generator using the following build.xml ant file :
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<project default="all">
<property file="build.properties" /> <property name="xdoclet.lib.dir" value="${xdoclet.home}/lib" /> <property name="xdoclet.plugins.dir" value="${xdoclet.home}/plugins" />
<property name="src.dir" value="${basedir}/src/main" /> <property name="java.src.dir" value="${src.dir}/java" /> <property name="resources.src.dir" value="${src.dir}/resources" /> <property name="ddl.dir" value="${src.dir}/ddl" />
<path id="entity.generator.classpath"> <dirset dir="${basedir}"> <include name="**/target/classes" /> </dirset> <fileset dir="${m2.repo}"> <include name="**/design2see/**/2.0/*.jar" /> <include name="**/commons-cli-1.0.jar" /> <include name="**/freemarker-2.3.3.jar" /> <include name="**/spring-2.0.6.jar" /> <include name="**/commons-logging-1.1.jar" /> <include name="**/xml-apis-2.0.2.jar" /> <include name="**/xerces-2.0.2.jar" /> <include name="**/bsf-2.3.0.jar" /> <include name="**/commons-beanutils-1.7.0.jar" /> </fileset> </path>
<target name="generate-entities"> <java classname="com.d2s.framework.tools.entitygenerator.EntityGenerator" classpathref="entity.generator.classpath"> <arg value="-applicationContextKey" /> <arg value="hrsample-model-context" /> <arg value="-templateResourcePath" /> <arg value="/com/d2s/framework/tools/entitygenerator" /> <arg value="-templateName" /> <arg value="HibernateXdocletEntity.ftl" /> <arg value="-outputDir" /> <arg value="${java.src.dir}" /> <arg value="-includePackages" /> <arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model" /> </java> </target>
<target name="all" depends="generate-entities" />
</project>
section.para: You may now have a look into the com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model package source directory. You may find the 2 generated classes :

listitem.para: Nameable.java for the Nameable interface (see the source code below).
Traceable.java for the Traceable interface.

section.programlisting:
/* * Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. */ package com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model; /** * Nameable component. *

* Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. *

* * @author Generated by Design2see * @version $LastChangedRevision$ */ public interface Nameable { /** * Gets the name. * * @hibernate.property * @hibernate.column * name = "NAME" * length = "64" * not-null = "true" * @return the name. */ java.lang.String getName(); /** * Sets the name. * * @param name * the name to set. */ void setName(java.lang.String name); }
section.para: These 2 java classes are in fact interfaces with getters and setters for the declared properties. In fact, you will never need any implementation for them since D2S will automatically handle their implementation for you at runtime using proxies. So you might wonder why we still need those interfaces instead of completely relying on the descriptors ? This is to benefit from the strong compilation enforcements, code completion in IDE, ... Anything you will need for quality, robustness and productivity when you are manipulating your components.
You may also notice that the generator took care of annotating the classes with hibernate xDoclet attributes. They will be used later to generate the necessary persistence meta-data.

section.title: Adding life-cycle behaviour
section.para: What about the handling of the Traceable properties ? We want them to follow the life-cycle of any traceable entity, i.e. :

listitem.para: Set the createTimestamp when the entity is persisted for the first time.
Set the lastUpdateTimestamp when the entity is updated in the persistent store.

section.para: It is time to write our first lines of java to achieve that. So let's create the life-cycle interceptor com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.service.TraceableLifecycleInterceptor java class as follow :

callout.para: The class inherits from the support class com.d2s.framework.model.component.service.EmptyLifecycleInterceptor which empty implements the required life-cycle interceptor interface com.d2s.framework.model.component.service.EmptyLifecycleInterceptor as well as the marker interface com.d2s.framework.model.component.service.IComponentService.
Whenever a Traceable component is persisted (saved for the first time), set its createTimestamp.
Return true to notify the framework that the state of the component has been updated.
Whenever a Traceable component is updated (subsequent saves), update its lastUpdateTimestamp.

section.para: We can now link the life-cycle interceptor to our Traceable interface bean descriptor as below :

callout.para: Defines an ordered list of life-cycle interceptors attached to the component.

section.title: Entities
section.para: As of now, we have only dealt with interfaces which are not entities by themselves. Describing an entity follows the exact same process except that we make its descriptor an entity descriptor which brings id (the entity identifier) and version (used for optimistic locking on concurrent access) standard properties.
So let's describe the City entity as below :
section.programlisting: <bean id="City" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.City" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="Nameable" /> </list> </property> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="zip" /> <property name="maxLength" value="10" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>

callout.para: Since City is an entity, we use a BasicEntityDescriptor which is a special kind of component descriptor.
This descriptor inherits from our Nameable interface as well as the standard com.d2s.framework.model.entity.IEntity descriptor bean.

section.para: Relaunching the D2S generator will produce the following class (City.java) :
section.programlisting:
/* * Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. */ package com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model; /** * City entity. *

* Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. *

* * @hibernate.mapping * default-access = "com.d2s.framework.model.persistence.hibernate.property.EntityPropertyAccessor" * @hibernate.class * table = "CITY" * dynamic-insert = "true" * dynamic-update = "true" * persister = "com.d2s.framework.model.persistence.hibernate.entity.persister.EntityProxyJoinedSubclassEntityPersister" * @author Generated by Design2see * @version $LastChangedRevision$ */ public interface City extends com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Nameable, com.d2s.framework.model.entity.IEntity { /** * @hibernate.id generator-class = "assigned" column = "ID" type = "string" * length = "36" *

* {@inheritDoc} */ java.io.Serializable getId(); /** * @hibernate.version column = "VERSION" unsaved-value = "null" *

* {@inheritDoc} */ Integer getVersion(); /** * Gets the zip. * * @hibernate.property * @hibernate.column * name = "ZIP" * length = "10" * @return the zip. */ java.lang.String getZip(); /** * Sets the zip. * * @param zip * the zip to set. */ void setZip(java.lang.String zip); }

callout.para: City is an entity so the generator made it inherit from com.d2s.framework.model.entity.IEntity which is a D2S framework base class.

section.para: You might notice that there are slightly more hibernate xDoclet tags (class level tags, id and version) to handle the entity persistence specifics. More important is that as for Nameable and Traceable, the City entity is not more than an interface. This brings to it a fundamental property which is multiple-inheritance; and this characteristic is also available among entities.

section.title: Components
section.para: A component is a data structure which is intended for being inlined in other components or entities. Like entities and interfaces, you can define properties and behaviour in a component. A component cannot live by itself. It is an elegant mean to factor common data and behaviour into higher level model parts.
So let's describe the ContactInfo component as below :
section.programlisting: <bean id="ContactInfo" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicComponentDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.ContactInfo" /> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="address" /> <property name="maxLength" value="256" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="phone" /> <property name="maxLength" value="32" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="email" /> <property name="maxLength" value="128" /> <property name="regexpPattern" value="[\w\-\.]*@[\w\-\.]*" /> <property name="regexpPatternSample" value="contact@acme.com" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>

callout.para: Since ContactInfo is an component, we use a BasicComponentDescriptor.

This is a special kind of string constraint enforcement through a regular expression; we want an email to conform to contain the @ sign, be without space and be only composed of literals plus '.' and '-'.
Whenever there is some kind of communication to initiate (a GUI notification for instance), this is an example of a correct value.

section.para: Relaunching the D2S generator will produce the following class (ContactInfo.java) :
section.programlisting:
/* * Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. */ package com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model; /** * ContactInfo component. *

* Generated by Design2see. All rights reserved. *

* * @author Generated by Design2see * @version $LastChangedRevision$ */ public interface ContactInfo extends com.d2s.framework.model.component.IComponent { /** * Gets the address. * * @hibernate.property * @hibernate.column * name = "ADDRESS" * length = "256" * @return the address. */ java.lang.String getAddress(); /** * Sets the address. * * @param address * the address to set. */ void setAddress(java.lang.String address); /** * Gets the phone. * * @hibernate.property * @hibernate.column * name = "PHONE" * length = "32" * @return the phone. */ java.lang.String getPhone(); /** * Sets the phone. * * @param phone * the phone to set. */ void setPhone(java.lang.String phone); /** * Gets the email. * * @hibernate.property * @hibernate.column * name = "EMAIL" * length = "128" * @return the email. */ java.lang.String getEmail(); /** * Sets the email. * * @param email * the email to set. */ void setEmail(java.lang.String email); }

callout.para: ContactInfo is an entity so the generator made it inherit from com.d2s.framework.model.component.IComponent which is a D2S framework base class.

section.para: You might have notice that the ContactInfo component is missing something : its relationship to the City entity.

section.title: Relationships
section.para: It's time to link together our first components together.

section.title: N-1 unidirectional
section.para: Let's first deal with the simple unidirectional association ContactInfo â†’ City. We are going to define a city property in the ContactInfo component.
The following XML fragment will do the trick :
section.programlisting: <bean id="ContactInfo" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicComponentDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.ContactInfo" /> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> ... <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicReferencePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="city" /> <property name="referencedDescriptor" ref="City" /> </bean> ... </list> </property> </bean>
section.para:
ContactInfo has a reference to the City entity so we describe this using a com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicReferencePropertyDescriptor.
We link the reference property descriptor to the City entity descriptor we described above (note the usage of the ref spring attribute).
Relaunching the D2S generator will update the ContactInfo.java source file we generated above, but since this is a unidirectional relationship, will remain the City.java file untouched. The following lines are added in the ContactInfo.java source file :

/** * Gets the city. * * @hibernate.many-to-one * cascade = "persist,merge,save-update,refresh,evict,replicate" * @hibernate.column * name = "CITY_ID" * @return the city. */ com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.City getCity();
/** * Sets the city. * * @param city * the city to set. */ void setCity(com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.City city);Again, the needed hibernate xDoclet tags are added to reflect the relationship between the component and the entity.
To end with the commons model part, let's define the Event entity :

<bean id="Event" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Event" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="Traceable" /> </list> </property> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicTextPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="text" /> <property name="maxLength" value="2048" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>
An event is a Traceable entity.
We use a com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicTextPropertyDescriptor instead of a com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor. This is to inform the framework the this property is likely to receive multi-line text; although there is no direct impact on the model layer, it might be useful in the view layer (e.g. : use a text area instead of a text field to display and edit the Event text property).
This first relationship is fairly simple since it is a n-1 unidirectional association. Of course, the D2S can seamlessly handle 1-n, 1-1 and n-n unidirectional and bi-directional associations and compositions (strong aggregations).
Now that we are done with the commons model part, let's see how we can handle the employees model part.

section.title: Inlined components
section.para: The Employee entity is fairly simple to describe giving what we already achieved.
Let's look at the XML fragment below :

<bean id="Employee" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Employee" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="Nameable" /> <ref local="Traceable" /> </list> </property> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="firstName" /> <property name="maxLength" value="32" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicStringPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="ssn" /> <property name="maxLength" value="10" /> <property name="regexpPattern" value="[\d]{10}" /> <property name="regexpPatternSample" value="0123456789" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicDatePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="birthDate" /> <property name="type" ref="DATE" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicDatePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="hireDate" /> <property name="type" ref="DATE" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicEnumerationPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="gender" /> <property name="enumerationName" value="GENDER" /> <property name="maxLength" value="1" /> <property name="mandatory" value="true" /> <property name="valuesAndIconImageUrls"> <map> <entry key="M" value="classpath:images/male-48x48.png" /> <entry key="F" value="classpath:images/female-48x48.png" /> </map> </property> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicReferencePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="contact" /> <property name="referencedDescriptor" ref="ContactInfo" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>
We defined a regular expression control on the ssn property since it must be composed of 10 and only 10 digits.
We don't care about the time information of this date; so we use a DATE type as opposed to the DATE_TIME type that we used for the Traceable interface.
This is a new kind of property descriptor. This one defines a finite choice of values for the property.
We define each of the values composing the choice for the gender enumeration (either 'M' or 'F') along with icons if available.
This is where we reference the ContactInfo component.
The employee description above shows that it is strictly equivalent - as far as description is concerned - to reference an entity or to inline a component (see the contact reference). The difference will be in the persistence store and in the views since an inlined component will have its attributes "merged" with the enclosing component as if they belonged to it.

section.title: 1-N unidirectional
section.para: You surely have noticed that we did not describe the 1-N composition between Employee and Event. This will be our first collection property and since this description will be re-used in views (to view and edit the events of an employee), we will put it in its own <bean> section so that we can assign it a spring id and reference it later :

<bean id="Employee-events" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicCollectionPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="events" /> <property name="composition" value="true" /> <property name="referencedDescriptor"> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicCollectionDescriptor"> <property name="collectionInterface" value="java.util.List" /> <property name="elementDescriptor" ref="Event" /> </bean> </property> </bean>
We are describing a collection relationship property. This is done using a com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicCollectionPropertyDescriptor.
We make this relationship a composition to express the fact that whenever an employee is deleted, the attached events must also be deleted.
A collection property descriptor always references a collection descriptor (which may be reused across different collection property descriptors)
We need an ordered list of event as specified in the analysis; so we use a java.util.List to achieve that. We could have used java.util.Set for a set semantic (no duplicate and unordered).
Our collection property lists events; so we reference the Event descriptor as being the element type of our collection.
Then we need to reference the Employee-events collection property descriptor in the Employee entity. This is done in a single line as shown below :

As a general rule, you have to remember that each and every bean definition in spring can be factored and re-used by making it a top-level bean and assigning it an id. This is what we have done for the Employee-events descriptor (for later reference but not for re-use). All the power of the Spring dependency injection container comes into play. For instance, we could easily decide to define short (32), medium (128) and long (512) parent string descriptors and have all our application string descriptors inherit from these. It would make the model more homogeneous and any change a matter of an instant. Following this principles, we encourage you to make re-usable descriptor bean libraries you can reference among your applications. Your descriptor sources will be more concise and more readable and maintainable.
Launching the D2S generator will generate the Employee.java source file :

Now that the employees model part is complete, let's deal with the organization.

section.title: Entity inheritance
section.para: The organization model part is the most complex of the example, since it involves entity inheritance (and polymorphism) and other kinds of relationships (1-1, bi-directional). So let's begin with the entity inheritance graph and we will deal with their relationships next.

<bean id="Company" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Company" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="Nameable" /> <ref local="Traceable" /> </list> </property> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicReferencePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="contact" /> <property name="referencedDescriptor" ref="ContactInfo" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>
<bean id="OrganizationalUnit" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.OrganizationalUnit" /> <property name="purelyAbstract" value="true" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="Nameable" /> <ref local="Traceable" /> </list> </property> <property name="propertyDescriptors"> <list> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicTextPropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="ouId" /> <property name="regexpPattern" value="[A-Z]{2}-[\d]{3}" /> <property name="regexpPatternSample" value="IS-123" /> <property name="maxLength" value="6" /> </bean> <bean class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.basic.BasicReferencePropertyDescriptor"> <property name="name" value="contact" /> <property name="referencedDescriptor" ref="ContactInfo" /> </bean> </list> </property> </bean>
<bean id="Department" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Department" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="OrganizationalUnit" /> </list> </property> </bean>
<bean id="Team" class="com.d2s.framework.model.descriptor.entity.basic.BasicEntityDescriptor"> <constructor-arg value="com.d2s.framework.hrsample.model.Team" /> <property name="ancestorDescriptors"> <list> <ref local="OrganizationalUnit" /> </list> </property> </bean>
An OrganizationalUnit will never be instantiated as such; only sub-entities will. This is why we define the entity as purely abstract.
Department inherits from OrganizationalUnit as do Team.
Pretty easy, no ? You describe entity inheritance exactly as you did previously for the interfaces. You don't have to care for anything else, the framework will handle it behind the scene for you.

You can see also that Company, OrganizationalUnit, and Employee have the same contact property as an inlined ContactInfo component. It is a perfect candidate for factoring. So we can make the contact property descriptor a top level bean and reference it in the 3 entities above. The result will be :
